DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES

FOR 1968



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: Development Estimates of Singapore for the year 1968 contained in Paper Cmd. 27 of 1967. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the last column of the Summary of Estimated Expenditure on pages 5 and 6 of the Paper. The heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on

Column: 908

the Order Paper Supplement will be taken first. But before doing so, I would like to draw Members' attention to the guillotine times. Hon. Members will have noticed from the guillotine times that we are today on a schedule that gives hon. Members less time than we had on the Main Estimates. While on the Main Estimates we have been able to apportion times in multiples of five minutes, it has been necessary for the Development Estimates to restrict time for debate on certain heads of expenditure to as low as two or three minutes. In order to assist hon. Members to make the best use of the available time, I would like to repeat something I said last year. What we will be considering in the Committee of Supply today are Development Estimates, and accordingly it will not be in order for Members to address remarks on policy or on the day-to-day running of the various departments and statutory bodies against whom items of proposed expenditure appear. Debate is confined to the proposed items of development expenditure, and I hope it will not be necessary for me to remind hon. Members of Standing Order 46 (1) which requires a Member to confine his observations to the subject under discussion and precludes the introduction of irrelevant matter. If it is the intention of any Member not to move an amendment standing in his name, advance information to the Clerk will also help in making the best use of the available time.

    Lastly, while I appreciate many Members have put in a great deal of effort in preparation for the debate, they must be prepared to modify and shorten their speeches having regard to the time available.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Thank you, Sir. There is a provision of $60,000 for works and buildings for which $15,500 is asked to be revoted. There is another revote for furniture and equipment. I would like to point out the lack of facilities in my two standard community centres - one is the Punggol Community Centre and the other at Punggol Point. They are Kampong Sungei Tengah Community centre, Jalan Serangoon Kechil Community Centre and another is located at 7½ m.s. Upper Serangoon Road. In my opinion, these centres are badly sited. No doubt the centres are there, but very few people go there to make use of the facilities. For example, in Jalan Serangoon Kechil the centre is sited in a rubber estate, much to the inconvenience of the people in the kampong which is about a quarter of a mile away and where the population is about a couple of thousand people. I do hope the

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I did not say that the Member for Punggol was consulted. I said the Member of Parliament of the constituency, if there was a Member, or else the sites were decided after the Prime Minister had visited these areas and had come to an agreement with the elders of the villages. Therefore, having sited these centres and having spent the money which was provided by the Ministry of Finance, it would be wasting public money to shift them. As my colleague, the Minister for Finance has said, if they feel that a certain centre is badly sited, they can move it themselves. There are lots of things which they can do themselves. For instance, the residents of Changi themselves built a community centre, and Changi is a rural area.

3.00 p.m.

    I would like to take up another point brought up by the Member for Punggol and that is the vacant land adjoining the community centre at Punggol Point which can be used to provide better facilities for the community centre. I would say the fault lies with him and his committee, because the People's Association have obtained permission from the owner of the land for its use, subject to the management committee of the community centre building a chain-link fence. They have done nothing so far and, therefore, they cannot make use of the facilities.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Punggol has also said that his community centre is badly sited because it is about a quarter of a mile away from the nearest concentration of population. Mr Speaker, Sir, you know that land in Singapore is rather limited, and if everyone wants to have a community centre right in front of his doorstep, it is something that is impossible. If a man is really imbued with civic consciousness and is willing to serve the public and, at the same time, wants to enjoy some of the facilities provided by a community centre, a distance of a quarter of a mile to the community centre is nothing.

    The Member for Anson has said that his community centre is too small for his constituency. I for one would like to see large areas being made available for community centres. But, unfortunately, as the hon. Member knows, there is a limitation of land in Anson and in most constituencies in Singapore, and land is quite costly. It is a question of putting every available piece of land to the best economic use.

    Similarly with Mountbatten, Mr Speaker, Sir. The present community centre there is sited about a quarter of a mile away from the place which the Member for Mountbatten thinks is a suitable site. I have my doubts, because if we were to spend money on building another community centre in the place indicated by him, in a year or two he would come round and say the same thing, that it is badly sited.

    So all in all, I think these community centres are sited in the best available spots and they can serve the community there quite well. For the information of the Member for Kampong Kembangan, what the Prime Minister said was not, "Where you have 200 or 300 people in an area, a community centre will be built." I would rather think it is nearer the truth if his statement was 300 or 400 families living in an area. I would like to say that, inasmuch as we would like to have dozens of community centres in a constituency, there is a limitation of land and funds.

    As for MacPherson Estate, I have every sympathy with the Member concerned and I will look into the problem.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister of Defence has said that the Punggol Point Community Centre is responsible for putting up a chain-link fence. Sir, we all know that it is very costly to put up a chain-link fence. In view of the small monthly subsidies given to community centres, I think the management committees will have to manage within the limited scope of the subsidies granted.

    The second point refers to the Staff Club House for the People's Association. While acknowledging the good work done by the staff of the People's Association to the community, I would like to ask the Minister (1) where is the Staff Club House to be located? want to extend the building. I am not talking about using the whole land -

    Sir, what is the Staff Club House for? The People's Association has a staff of about 1,200 who are responsible for the running of, I think, 183 or 184 community centres. As the Member for Punggol has pointed out, the staff are: spread all over the island and they have few opportunities of meeting one another socially or of discussing their work. All members of the staff are citizens of Singapore and I am sure the Member for Punggol will not deny a section of our citizens facilities for social intercourse and sporting netivities. That is one of the reasons why we decided that there should be a Staff Club House for the, staff of the People's Association. Another reason is to give them the facilities to meet and talk about their problems. I think the Member for Punggol is aware that we just held a staff seminar of the People's Association: to discuss ways and means ot improving their work in the community centres so that there can be an interchange of views between the members of the staff of the People's Association.

    The Member for Punggol has also asked me whether we can afford a Staff Club House. Surely, if we cannot afford it, the Minister for Finance will not have allowed it to be in the vote! The answer is 'Yes'. This is going to be a substantive Staff Club House situated next

to the headquarters of the People's Association and the rugger field in Mountbatten Road. The first priority for its use will be confined to members of the staff of the People's Association. But we do not like to have any government facilities lying idle and I have already proposed to them that they can also entertain applications at times - I think it will be quite often - from any organisations, bodies or groups of people who want to use it.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, our educational TV service was launched, as you know, on the 30th of January. 1967, after nine months of planning and preparation. The service is designed to improve the quality of teaching and to supplement ordinary classroom work. The programmes for the first year were directed to Secondary I and II students and, as the Member for Choa Chu Kang has pointed out, were very well received.

    But towards the end of the year, it was felt that the time was ripe for the

Column: 921

expansion of the educational television service to cover other classes in stages from Primary III to pre-University level for 1968. So plans for expansion were drawn up and submitted to the Economic Planning Unit for consideration. The Economic Planning Unit thought that the service should consolidate itself before launching out into new fields and advised deferment of the expansion proposals. That is why the small sum was provided for expenditure next year.

    However, despite financial restrictions, staffing shortages and the comparatively brief experience in this field, ETV has made remarkable headway. This was confirmed by the winning of a special prize in a contest in Japan, which was open to television establishments all over the world, including the B.B.C. For the information of the Member for Choa Chu Kang, since then the Economic Planning Unit has been having second thoughts on the matter, and I understand that a review of the proposals for limited expansion is being undertaken now.

    Mr Tang See Chim: I am glad to hear that the E.P.U, has reconsidered its decision and that possibly a further sum may be voted on. I am quite satisfied and indeed very glad to hear what the Minister has said, and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng (Joo Chiat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 20 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (001) of subhead 301.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that the University has essentially all the basic requirements to teach the various academic subjects leading to the degrees conferred by her. These, to my mind, are not enough to grace the dignity of this queen of higher education. What she really needs to crown her glory is a University Hall that will have enough space to cater for the annual convocations, act as an examination hall, and be utilised as an indoor stadium for

Column: 922

badminton and other indoor sporting activities.

    It is, therefore, a crying shame that this institution, with an associated history of providing higher education for some 60 years, has yet to be provided with the necessary funds to build such a hail, whereas junior institutions such as secondary schools and vocational institutes can boast of such facilities.

    Will the Minister for Education, who is an old boy of the University, reconsider with some sympathy the urgent need for this so-called Great Hall of the University?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the building of a Great Hall for the University of Singapore has been receiving attention even before the former Oei Tiong Ham Hall was converted into offices to cater for the expansion of the University. The present thinking is to establish a Sports and Recreation Centre in which a multi purpose hall, as suggested by the Member, for convocations, examinations, lectures, debates, conferences, seminars, theatrical productions, film shows, and recreation, will be prominently featured. The complex will be built on the land near the existing playing-field and the whole area, in fact, is now being filled up in anticipation of this development.

    However, in view of our limited financial resources and the need to give priority to other more urgent development projects, the development of this centre has not received urgent attention. The cost of implementing this project will therefore have to come mainly from donations, and I hope the public, especially the alumni of the University, who have benefited directly from their old University, will respond generously to the call for financial assistance.

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad that some form of appeal will be launched sometime in the near future, so that the various alumni of our University will make sure that our University will be an institution of some

greatness in the form of a Great Hall. With that, Sir, I beg to withdraw my amendment.
